Class.name: BioMaterialCharacteristics
Class.Description: Properties of the biomaterial before treated in any manner for the purposes of the experiment.

Class.name: Age
Class.Description: The time period elapsed since an identifiable point in the life cycle of an organism. If a developmental stage is specified, the identifiable point would be the beginning of that stage. Otherwise the identifiable point must be specified such as planting (e.g. 3 days post planting).

Class.name: BioMaterialPurity
Class.Description: A measure of homogeneity of a biomaterial. For example, an expression of the percentage of a tumor biopsy that is tumor cells.

Class.name: Biometrics
Class.Description: Physical properties of the BioMaterial e. g. mass or height

Class.name: BioSourceProvider
Class.Description: The resource (e.g. company, hospital, geographical location) used to obtain or purchase the biomaterial.

Class.name: BioSourceType
Class.Description: The form in which the BioMaterial was obtained/maintained e.g. frozen, fresh etc. Note can be used to describe BioSamples as well as BioSources.

Class.name: CellLine
Class.Description: The identifier for the established culture of a metazoan cell if one was used as a biomaterial.

Class.name: CellType
Class.Description: CellType, the type of cell used in the experiment if non mixed, if mixed the TargetedCellType should be used, example of instances, epithelial, glial etc.

Class.name: ChromosomalAberrationClassification
Class.Description: An irregularity in the number or structure of chromosomes, usually in the form of a gain (duplication), loss (deletion), exchange (translocation), or alteration in sequence (inversion) of genetic material. Excludes simple changes in sequence such as mutations, and is usually detectable by cytogenetic and microscopic techniques such as FISH.

Class.name: ClinicalTreatment
Class.Description: The current clinical treatment(s) of the patient from which the biosource is derived.

Class.name: DevelopmentalStage
Class.Description: The developmental stage of the organism's life cycle during which the biomaterial was extracted.

Class.name: DiseaseStaging
Class.Description: The stage or progression of a disease in an organism. Includes pathological staging of cancers and other disease progression.

Class.name: DiseaseState
Class.Description: The name of the pathology diagnosed in the organism from which the biomaterial was derived. The disease state is normal if no disease has been diagnosed.

Class.name: EnvironmentalHistory
Class.Description: A description of the conditions the organism has been exposed to that are not one of the variables under study.

Class.name: Bedding
Class.Description: Refers to the bedding material present in an animals housing.

Class.name: ClinicalHistory
Class.Description: The BioMaterial's (i.e., the patient's) medical record as background information relevant to the experiment.

Class.name: FamilyHistory
Class.Description: Relevant aspects of genetic preconditions or family member's clinical history.

Class.name: Generation
Class.Description: The number of cell passages if the organism or organism part that is cultured is unicellular or a cell culture otherwise the number of generations.

Class.name: GeographicLocation
Class.Description: A descriptor of the location from which a BioMaterial was obtained, e.g. country, region, grid reference.

Class.name: GrowthCondition
Class.Description: A description of the conditions used to grow organisms or parts of the organism. This includes isolated environments such as cultures and open environments such as field studies.

Class.name: Atmosphere
Class.Description: The atmospheric conditions used to culture or grow an organism.

Class.name: BarrierFacility
Class.Description: Rating of containment system for the protection of organisms from infectious agents.

Class.name: Humidity
Class.Description: The humidity that the biosource is exposed to.

Class.name: Light
Class.Description: The photoperiod and type (e.g., natural, restricted wavelength) of light exposure.

Class.name: Media
Class.Description: The physical state or matrix used to provide nutrients to the organism (e.g., liquid, agar, soil) .

Class.name: Nutrients
Class.Description: The food provided to the organism (e.g., chow, fertilizer, DEMM 10%FBS, etc.).

Class.name: PopulationDensity
Class.Description: The concentration range of the organism.

Class.name: Temperature
Class.Description: The temperature that a biosource is exposed to.

Class.name: Water
Class.Description: Water consumed by or enveloping the organism that the biosource is derived from.

Class.name: Host
Class.Description: Organisms or organism parts used as a designed part of the culture (e.g., red blood cells, stromal cells).

Class.name: PathogenTest
Class.Description: Tests and results for pathogens infecting organism from which the biosource is derived

Class.name: SamplingTimePoint
Class.Description: A descriptor of the time point that a sample was taken. Not to be used where the sample is part of a time course. SamplingTimePoint is not related to age. An instance could be summer, a date, a time, or a range value.

Class.name: GeneticModification
Class.Description: The genetic modification introduced into the organism from which the biomaterial was derived. Examples of genetic modification include specification of a transgene or the gene knocked-out or details of transient transfection.

Class.name: Histology
Class.Description: Microscopic morphology of tissues.

Class.name: Individual
Class.Description: Identifier or name of the individual organism from which the biomaterial was derived.

Class.name: IndividualGeneticCharacteristics
Class.Description: The genotype of the individual organism from which the biomaterial was derived. Individual genetic characteristics include polymorphisms, disease alleles, and haplotypes.

Class.name: Allele
Class.Description: One of two or more alternative forms of a gene or marker sequence and differing from other alleles at one or more mutational sites based on phenotype or sequence. Polymorphisms are included in this definition.

Class.name: Genotype
Class.Description: The total sum of the genetic information of an organism that is known and relevant to the experiment being performed, including chromosomal, plasmid, viral or other genetic material which has been introduced into the organism either prior to or during the experiment.

Class.name: Haplotype
Class.Description: The genotype of a single chromosome (i.e., the haploid genotype) that is known and relevant to the experiment being performed.

Class.name: IndividualChromosomalAbnormality
Class.Description: An abnormality in the number or structure of chromosomes in the biomaterial from an individual organism, detected by karyotyping or other methods. E.g., a B-cell lymphoma from a patient has an abnormal karyotype 48,XY,t(1;2)(p22;p11),+3,+12.

Class.name: Ploidy
Class.Description: The number of single sets of chromosomes in the cell or an organism e.g., haploid, diploid, triploid, etc.

Class.name: Observation
Class.Description: Observation will record the macroscopic examination of the biomaterial.

Class.name: Organism
Class.Description: The genus and species (and subspecies) of the organism from which the biomaterial is derived from.

Class.name: OrganismPart
Class.Description: The part of organism's anatomy or substance arising from an organism from which the biomaterial was derived, excludes cells. E.g. tissue, organ, system, sperm, blood or body location (arm).

Class.name: DiseaseLocation
Class.Description: Anatomical location(s) of disease.

Class.name: OrganismStatus
Class.Description: The stage premortem or postmortem at which the sample was processed for extraction of biomaterials.

Class.name: Phenotype
Class.Description: The observable form taken by some character (or group of characters) in an individual or an organism, excluding pathology and disease. The detectable outward manifestations of a specific genotype.

Class.name: Serotype
Class.Description: An antigenic property of a cell (e.g. bacteria, RBC) or virus identified by serological methods

Class.name: Sex
Class.Description: Term applied to any organism able to undergo sexual reproduction in order to differentiate the individuals or types involved. Sexual reproduction is defined as the ability to exchange genetic material with the potential of recombinant progeny.

Class.name: StrainOrLine
Class.Description: A strain or line is an animal or plant offspring that has a single ancestral breeding pair or parent as a result of brother x sister or parent x offspring matings. This class is extended to include F1 offspring and established breeding lines. For microbes, these are isolates derived from nature or in the laboratory.

Class.name: Cultivar
Class.Description: a plant variety obtained in agriculture in horticulture

Class.name: Ecotype
Class.Description: a biotype resulting from selection in a particular habitat, e.g. the A. thaliana Ecotype Ler

Class.name: TargetedCellType
Class.Description: The target cell type is the cell of primary interest. The biomaterial may be derived from a mixed population of cells although only one cell type is of interest.

Class.name: Test
Class.Description: An assay performed on a biomaterial for the purposes of determining one or more biomaterial characteristics e.g. clinical chemistry.

Class.name: TestResult
Class.Description: TestResult is the recorded value of the test outcome.

Class.name: TestType
Class.Description: Descriptor of the Test performed e.g. Leukocyte count

Class.name: TumorGrading
Class.Description: A descriptor used in cancer biology to describe abnormalities of tumor cells. E.g. an instance from NCI Thesaurus.

Class.name: BioSequenceType
Class.Description: Controlled terms for descriptors indicating the type of biosequence. Types may be physical (e.g. BAC, cDNA clone), or computational (e.g. unigene cluster, consensus).

Class.name: PhysicalBioSequenceType
Class.Description: A physical biosequence type represents biological sequence that can be physically placed (spotted or synthesized) on an array e.g. BAC, PAC.

Class.name: SequenceOntologyBioSequenceType
Class.Description: Descriptors of biosequence based on the Sequence Ontology (SO) project.

Class.name: TheoreticalBioSequenceType
Class.Description: A theoretical biosequence type is an abstraction used for annotation design of elements, e.g. gene, intron.

Class.name: SequenceOntologyBioSequenceType
Class.Description: Descriptors of biosequence based on the Sequence Ontology (SO) project.

Class.name: ExperimentDesignType
Class.Description: The ExperimentDesignType is the high level description for studies such as "time series", "dose response", etc.

Class.name: BiologicalProperty
Class.Description: A biological property experiment design type is where an intrinsic characteristic of an organism(s) or biological system is examined.

Class.name: BioMolecularAnnotation
Class.Description: BioMolecularAnnotation experiment design types are those which are designed to investigate functions, processes, locations and identity at the molecular level e.g. binding site identification, genotyping.

Class.name: EpidemiologicalDesign
Class.Description: An epidemiological experiment design type is where the biosource history is studied e.g. environmental, clinical and family history.

Class.name: MethodologicalDesign
Class.Description: A methodological experiment design type investigates differences caused by application of protocols, hardware, software and bioassay relationships, e.g. quality control, replicates, loop.

Class.name: PerturbationalDesign
Class.Description: A perturbational design type is where the organism(s) are treated or manipulated or modified, for example a genetic modification, somatic modification

Class.name: TechnologicalDesign
Class.Description: The purpose(s) for which the array is used within an experiment, e.g. to assess the transcriptome, the genomic content, or to identify transcription factor binding sites.

Class.name: ProtocolType
Class.Description: A controlled set of terms to provide a descriptor for the type of protocol.

Class.name: DataTransformationProtocolType
Class.Description: The process by which derived BioAssays are created from measured BioAssays and/or derived BioAssays.

Class.name: ExperimentalProtocolType
Class.Description: All protocols which involve treatment of a biomaterial or an array during the course of a microarray experiment.

Class.name: HigherLevelAnalysisProtocolType
Class.Description: A protocol which yields a dataset(s) from which biological conclusions can be derived. E.g. clustering (not normalization or averaging).

Class.name: ExperimentalFactorCategory
Class.Description: A factor category describes factors which are examined in the experiment, e.g. disease_state, where the factor values are ALL and AML.

Class.name: BiologicalFactorCategory
Class.Description: Factors that relate to properties of the biomaterial, its treatment, or its growth.

Class.name: Action
Class.Description: Procedures used during treatment.

Class.name: AtomicAction
Class.Description: An atomic action is a single step process on the biomaterial, e.g. mix by inversion, wait, add

Class.name: ComplexAction
Class.Description: Complex actions are composed of multiple steps (as opposed to AtomicAction) e.g. mRNA labeling, protein purification.

Class.name: BioMaterialCharacteristicCategory
Class.Description: General descriptor of a BioMaterialCharacteristic category. Such as strain or line where the name of the strain or line is encoded in the FactorValue.

Class.name: BioMaterialCharacteristics
Class.Description: Properties of the biomaterial before treated in any manner for the purposes of the experiment.

Class.name: Age
Class.Description: The time period elapsed since an identifiable point in the life cycle of an organism. If a developmental stage is specified, the identifiable point would be the beginning of that stage. Otherwise the identifiable point must be specified such as planting (e.g. 3 days post planting).

Class.name: BioMaterialPurity
Class.Description: A measure of homogeneity of a biomaterial. For example, an expression of the percentage of a tumor biopsy that is tumor cells.

Class.name: Biometrics
Class.Description: Physical properties of the BioMaterial e. g. mass or height

Class.name: BioSourceProvider
Class.Description: The resource (e.g. company, hospital, geographical location) used to obtain or purchase the biomaterial.

Class.name: BioSourceType
Class.Description: The form in which the BioMaterial was obtained/maintained e.g. frozen, fresh etc. Note can be used to describe BioSamples as well as BioSources.

Class.name: CellLine
Class.Description: The identifier for the established culture of a metazoan cell if one was used as a biomaterial.

Class.name: CellType
Class.Description: CellType, the type of cell used in the experiment if non mixed, if mixed the TargetedCellType should be used, example of instances, epithelial, glial etc.

Class.name: ChromosomalAberrationClassification
Class.Description: An irregularity in the number or structure of chromosomes, usually in the form of a gain (duplication), loss (deletion), exchange (translocation), or alteration in sequence (inversion) of genetic material. Excludes simple changes in sequence such as mutations, and is usually detectable by cytogenetic and microscopic techniques such as FISH.

Class.name: ClinicalTreatment
Class.Description: The current clinical treatment(s) of the patient from which the biosource is derived.

Class.name: DevelopmentalStage
Class.Description: The developmental stage of the organism's life cycle during which the biomaterial was extracted.

Class.name: DiseaseStaging
Class.Description: The stage or progression of a disease in an organism. Includes pathological staging of cancers and other disease progression.

Class.name: DiseaseState
Class.Description: The name of the pathology diagnosed in the organism from which the biomaterial was derived. The disease state is normal if no disease has been diagnosed.

Class.name: EnvironmentalHistory
Class.Description: A description of the conditions the organism has been exposed to that are not one of the variables under study.

Class.name: Bedding
Class.Description: Refers to the bedding material present in an animals housing.

Class.name: ClinicalHistory
Class.Description: The BioMaterial's (i.e., the patient's) medical record as background information relevant to the experiment.

Class.name: FamilyHistory
Class.Description: Relevant aspects of genetic preconditions or family member's clinical history.

Class.name: Generation
Class.Description: The number of cell passages if the organism or organism part that is cultured is unicellular or a cell culture otherwise the number of generations.

Class.name: GeographicLocation
Class.Description: A descriptor of the location from which a BioMaterial was obtained, e.g. country, region, grid reference.

Class.name: GrowthCondition
Class.Description: A description of the conditions used to grow organisms or parts of the organism. This includes isolated environments such as cultures and open environments such as field studies.

Class.name: Atmosphere
Class.Description: The atmospheric conditions used to culture or grow an organism.

Class.name: BarrierFacility
Class.Description: Rating of containment system for the protection of organisms from infectious agents.

Class.name: Humidity
Class.Description: The humidity that the biosource is exposed to.

Class.name: Light
Class.Description: The photoperiod and type (e.g., natural, restricted wavelength) of light exposure.

Class.name: Media
Class.Description: The physical state or matrix used to provide nutrients to the organism (e.g., liquid, agar, soil) .

Class.name: Nutrients
Class.Description: The food provided to the organism (e.g., chow, fertilizer, DEMM 10%FBS, etc.).

Class.name: PopulationDensity
Class.Description: The concentration range of the organism.

Class.name: Temperature
Class.Description: The temperature that a biosource is exposed to.

Class.name: Water
Class.Description: Water consumed by or enveloping the organism that the biosource is derived from.

Class.name: Host
Class.Description: Organisms or organism parts used as a designed part of the culture (e.g., red blood cells, stromal cells).

Class.name: PathogenTest
Class.Description: Tests and results for pathogens infecting organism from which the biosource is derived

Class.name: SamplingTimePoint
Class.Description: A descriptor of the time point that a sample was taken. Not to be used where the sample is part of a time course. SamplingTimePoint is not related to age. An instance could be summer, a date, a time, or a range value.

Class.name: GeneticModification
Class.Description: The genetic modification introduced into the organism from which the biomaterial was derived. Examples of genetic modification include specification of a transgene or the gene knocked-out or details of transient transfection.

Class.name: Histology
Class.Description: Microscopic morphology of tissues.

Class.name: Individual
Class.Description: Identifier or name of the individual organism from which the biomaterial was derived.

Class.name: IndividualGeneticCharacteristics
Class.Description: The genotype of the individual organism from which the biomaterial was derived. Individual genetic characteristics include polymorphisms, disease alleles, and haplotypes.

Class.name: Allele
Class.Description: One of two or more alternative forms of a gene or marker sequence and differing from other alleles at one or more mutational sites based on phenotype or sequence. Polymorphisms are included in this definition.

Class.name: Genotype
Class.Description: The total sum of the genetic information of an organism that is known and relevant to the experiment being performed, including chromosomal, plasmid, viral or other genetic material which has been introduced into the organism either prior to or during the experiment.

Class.name: Haplotype
Class.Description: The genotype of a single chromosome (i.e., the haploid genotype) that is known and relevant to the experiment being performed.

Class.name: IndividualChromosomalAbnormality
Class.Description: An abnormality in the number or structure of chromosomes in the biomaterial from an individual organism, detected by karyotyping or other methods. E.g., a B-cell lymphoma from a patient has an abnormal karyotype 48,XY,t(1;2)(p22;p11),+3,+12.

Class.name: Ploidy
Class.Description: The number of single sets of chromosomes in the cell or an organism e.g., haploid, diploid, triploid, etc.

Class.name: Observation
Class.Description: Observation will record the macroscopic examination of the biomaterial.

Class.name: Organism
Class.Description: The genus and species (and subspecies) of the organism from which the biomaterial is derived from.

Class.name: OrganismPart
Class.Description: The part of organism's anatomy or substance arising from an organism from which the biomaterial was derived, excludes cells. E.g. tissue, organ, system, sperm, blood or body location (arm).

Class.name: DiseaseLocation
Class.Description: Anatomical location(s) of disease.

Class.name: OrganismStatus
Class.Description: The stage premortem or postmortem at which the sample was processed for extraction of biomaterials.

Class.name: Phenotype
Class.Description: The observable form taken by some character (or group of characters) in an individual or an organism, excluding pathology and disease. The detectable outward manifestations of a specific genotype.

Class.name: Serotype
Class.Description: An antigenic property of a cell (e.g. bacteria, RBC) or virus identified by serological methods

Class.name: Sex
Class.Description: Term applied to any organism able to undergo sexual reproduction in order to differentiate the individuals or types involved. Sexual reproduction is defined as the ability to exchange genetic material with the potential of recombinant progeny.

Class.name: StrainOrLine
Class.Description: A strain or line is an animal or plant offspring that has a single ancestral breeding pair or parent as a result of brother x sister or parent x offspring matings. This class is extended to include F1 offspring and established breeding lines. For microbes, these are isolates derived from nature or in the laboratory.

Class.name: Cultivar
Class.Description: a plant variety obtained in agriculture in horticulture

Class.name: Ecotype
Class.Description: a biotype resulting from selection in a particular habitat, e.g. the A. thaliana Ecotype Ler

Class.name: TargetedCellType
Class.Description: The target cell type is the cell of primary interest. The biomaterial may be derived from a mixed population of cells although only one cell type is of interest.

Class.name: Test
Class.Description: An assay performed on a biomaterial for the purposes of determining one or more biomaterial characteristics e.g. clinical chemistry.

Class.name: TestResult
Class.Description: TestResult is the recorded value of the test outcome.

Class.name: TestType
Class.Description: Descriptor of the Test performed e.g. Leukocyte count

Class.name: TumorGrading
Class.Description: A descriptor used in cancer biology to describe abnormalities of tumor cells. E.g. an instance from NCI Thesaurus.

Class.name: Compound
Class.Description: A drug, solvent, chemical, etc., with a property that can be measured such as concentration.

Class.name: LabelCompound
Class.Description: Compounds that are used for labeling extracts.

Class.name: EnvironmentalFactorCategory
Class.Description: Factors that relate to properties of the environmental history of the biomaterial, its treatment, or its growth.

Class.name: MethodologicalFactorCategory
Class.Description: The effects on results of changing protocols, hardware, software, or people performing the experiments are studied Examples are comparison of data across different labeling protocols, scanners, image quantification software, or laboratories.

Class.name: HardwareVariation
Class.Description: The effects of different hardware, types of hardware, or models of hardware on experimental results are studied.

Class.name: OperatorVariation
Class.Description: The effects of different investigators, laboratories, or organizations on experimental results are studied.

Class.name: ProtocolType
Class.Description: A controlled set of terms to provide a descriptor for the type of protocol.

Class.name: DataTransformationProtocolType
Class.Description: The process by which derived BioAssays are created from measured BioAssays and/or derived BioAssays.

Class.name: ExperimentalProtocolType
Class.Description: All protocols which involve treatment of a biomaterial or an array during the course of a microarray experiment.

Class.name: HigherLevelAnalysisProtocolType
Class.Description: A protocol which yields a dataset(s) from which biological conclusions can be derived. E.g. clustering (not normalization or averaging).

Class.name: SoftwareVariation
Class.Description: The effects of different software, software packages, or software versions on experimental results are studied.

Class.name: TechnologyType
Class.Description: The technology type or platform of the reporters on the array.
